item.title: By: Can Known embed a Tableau viz? Does Tableau play nice with Google's Chart API?
item.dc:creator: Can Known embed a Tableau viz? Does Tableau play nice with Google's Chart API?
item.description: […] Jerome Cukier for the tip on embedding a viz.  You saved me a ton of time and research. […]
item.content:encoded: […] Jerome Cukier for the tip on embedding a viz.  You saved me a ton of time and research. […]

item.title: By: Oscar
item.dc:creator: Oscar
item.description: HI, I tried your quick iframe hack and it worked! For the newbies out there (like me) there's one caveat, you need to install the iframes plug-in if your site is a Wordpress.org blog. Once you install the plug-in, just copy and paste Jerome's code and replace with your own URL. I also found that if you set the dashboard size to "automatic" it might not resize properly according to your site's layout. If you don't want to bother using fixed width and height measures, theres an option in Tableau 8.2 to size the dashboard or story at "medium/large" blog size. This worked perfect for me.
item.content:encoded:
HI,
I tried your quick iframe hack and it worked! For the newbies out there (like me) there’s one caveat, you need to install the iframes plug-in if your site is a WordPress.org blog. Once you install the plug-in, just copy and paste Jerome’s code and replace with your own URL.
I also found that if you set the dashboard size to “automatic” it might not resize properly according to your site’s layout. If you don’t want to bother using fixed width and height measures, theres an option in Tableau 8.2 to size the dashboard or story at “medium/large” blog size. This worked perfect for me.

item.title: By: dimeler
item.dc:creator: dimeler
item.description:
Hey Jerome. Great post! I like the thorough explanation of each line of code. It helps a beginner like me learn and not just copy/paste. I'm having the same problem as the user above. Still trying to research a way to get this to work. You can see what I've done over at my wordpress blog: https://dimeler.wordpress.com/ .
If you take a look at my post, I'm having the same issue when I post the Tableau Public viz code where there‚Äôs a ‚ÄúPlay‚Äù sign in the middle of it which does nothing when you click on it. When I try your iframe code, I get the same thing where there's just a link to my Tableau Public workbook. I understand this is an older blog post, but any insight would be greatly appreciated! Looking forward to your response.
item.content:encoded:
Hey Jerome. Great post! I like the thorough explanation of each line of code. It helps a beginner like me learn and not just copy/paste. I’m having the same problem as the user above. Still trying to research a way to get this to work. You can see what I’ve done over at my wordpress blog: https://dimeler.wordpress.com/ .

If you take a look at my post, I’m having the same issue when I post the Tableau Public viz code where there‚Äôs a ‚ÄúPlay‚Äù sign in the middle of it which does nothing when you click on it. When I try your iframe code, I get the same thing where there’s just a link to my Tableau Public workbook. I understand this is an older blog post, but any insight would be greatly appreciated! Looking forward to your response.

item.title: By: evetslefurac
item.dc:creator: evetslefurac
item.description:
Hi,
I tried your iframe code and the only thing appearing is the hyperlink to my data stuff at Tableau website. I expected the actual graph to appear and being interactive.
But also, if I copy the long code provided by Tableau Public the graph on my webpage is static (not interactive), there's a "Play" sign in the middle of it which does nothing when you click on it and, finally, the graph overlaps on the following text (I place my graph between two paragraphs).
item.content:encoded:
Hi,

I tried your iframe code and the only thing appearing is the hyperlink to my data stuff at Tableau website. I expected the actual graph to appear and being interactive.

But also, if I copy the long code provided by Tableau Public the graph on my webpage is static (not interactive), there’s a “Play” sign in the middle of it which does nothing when you click on it and, finally, the graph overlaps on the following text (I place my graph between two paragraphs).

item.title: By: jerome
item.dc:creator: jerome
item.description: you should look at one of my posts that contains a tableau dashboard, do view source and copy the code changing the name of the dashboard with your own. It's been a long time since I last tried this, so it's entirely possible that Tableau has come up with a better way of doing this since then.
item.content:encoded: you should look at one of my posts that contains a tableau dashboard, do view source and copy the code changing the name of the dashboard with your own. It’s been a long time since I last tried this, so it’s entirely possible that Tableau has come up with a better way of doing this since then.

item.title: By: John Burrett
item.dc:creator: John Burrett
item.description:
Hi Jerome - thanks for the solution. As I relatively new to this (trying to embed Tableau vix into Wordpress) , could you show me the iframe solution above, as it fits into the whole body of the embedding code?
Thank you in advance
item.content:encoded:
Hi Jerome – thanks for the solution. As I relatively new to this (trying to embed Tableau vix into WordPress) , could you show me the iframe solution above, as it fits into the whole body of the embedding code?

Thank you in advance

item.title: By: emily.bronte
item.dc:creator: emily.bronte
item.description: the best part is that In tableau, when creating dashboards, I have always used the option to size them exactly at a precise size and I recommend you do that too. Then add 2-6 px to each dimension and use that as width and height. thanks regard emily.bronte <a href="http://www.keepitplanned.com/cities-to-visit-in-california/" rel="nofollow">Cities to Visit in California</a>
item.content:encoded:
the best part is that In tableau, when creating dashboards, I have always used the option to size them exactly at a precise size and I recommend you do that too. Then add 2-6 px to each dimension and use that as width and height.
thanks
regard
emily.bronte
Cities to Visit in California
